I want to learn a functional programming language - just to know how it works -, Currently I'm confused between Haskell & Scala  ? 
Which One I should Learn the pure functional one or the mixed paradigm one ??

data.message: LOL انا بس محتار بين ال 2 فكنت عايز اسمع اراء الناس التانية .. مش لازم ال2 دول اكسرهم واتناقش في حاجة براهم

I believe the mixed-paradigm is more practical and the pure functional will help with the concepts more, if you have the time, start with Haskell to get a feel of pure functional concepts then after a few toy projects, move to Scala because it has more real-life usage and more benefit to you as an engineer and a developer, some companies use it already, if you don't have time, ignore Haskell and go with Scala, that's just my opinion :)
I second Diaa's point, Scala is very practical and pragmatic, and you get to learn a bit of Java in the process too.
Thanks for your comments, I started tinkering with Scala anyway. Maybe I will have a look over Clojure or Scheme later
